_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Santa Isabel Old and New Wastewater Treatment Plant is located at the State Road PR-5538 Km 0.5 Interior Velazquez Ward, Puerto Rico, 00757.   The New wastewater treatment plant (3.0 MG) and the Old (1.5 MG) used only for re-circulation are owned by Puerto Rico Aqueduct and Sewer Authority (PRASA) which is a Government Agency.  PRASA has developed the RMP following the Program #3 for the Management and Prevention of Risks associated with the storage and handling of the toxic substance used as for water disinfection.  The RMP was prepared in compliance with EPA 40 CFR Part 68.  The Prevention Program was prepared in accordance with OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation, as established in 29 CFR Part 1910.119.



Accidental Release:

It is PRASA policy to comply with EPA and OSHA Federal and State applicable requirements. Chlorine is a toxic substance regulated by EPA, for that reason the facility is observing the appropriated engineering controls.  The  design is to improve safety and as a part of the Prevention Plan implanted to protect the wellness of workers, employees, contractors, visitors and immediately surrounding areas and inhabitants.



The Stationary Source and Regulated Substance handled.

Santa Isabel Wastewater Treatment Plants is located close to the Mar Caribe where the plant discharges the treated water.  The chlorine is used as a disinfectant to destroy the microorganism that could cause illness in humans and contamination of the ocean.



The chlorine is delivered from the San Juan Chlorine Warehouse and Distribution Center to the plant in one (1) ton containers.  For this plant two containers are connected to chlorinators, the chlorine flows to the vacuum and from it the chlorine solution is sent to ejectors, where it is combined with the used water at the end of plant process. 



Worst Case Scenario:

The Worst Case Scenario for the plant was determined as indicated in the EPA Wastewater Treatment Plant, as per Appendix F Supplemental

Risk Management Program Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants.  This guidance considers the release of the Chlorine Gas of the entire container (2,000 pounds) during 10 minutes and other specifications related to the weather conditions and a radio of 1.3 miles, for a chlorine concentration equal or higher than 3 ppm, which is the American Industrial Hygiene Association exposure limit above which it is determined human health will be affected.  Using the Marplot Simulator and the US Census 2010, it was identified that 4,382 public receptors are inside the 1.3 miles radio. Environmental receptors (state parks, or official designated wildlife preserves) are located within this radio area.  The ALOHA Modeling Dispersion Program was used to simulate the gas dispersion. 



Alternative Case Scenario:

The more realistic scenario was also simulated as per EPA Wastewater Treatment Plants parameters, as a release of the total content of a 2,000 pounds container, but throughout a valve seal rupture.  In such case the end point distance is calculated as 0.2 miles and  58 public receptor were identified over the most recent map. There are two environmental receptors located within the radio area.



General Accident Release Prevention Program 

PRASA is actually in a very aggressive operation to implement a Prevention Plan to ensure the maintenance and mechanical integrity of the facility which will improve significantly the safety scope of the current prevention plans.  Standard Operational Procedures (SOPs) are already in place to comply the OSHA and PROSHO requirements in order to keep all the involved parties aware of the hazardous and risk related to the chlorine.  List of all SOPs are indicated in the PSM report and are located in the plant.



Emergency Response Program:

PRASA has various SOPs to manage emergency programs associated to a release of the chemical and also related to the emergency actions to be taken before and after hurricanes and other atmospherics e

vents.



Five years Accident History:

No mayor release of chlorine in excess of ten (10) lbs has been reported during the last five years. 



Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

It is still needed to reinforced administrative activities related to containers handling and transportation.
